Title: Insomnia's Negative Sequelae On Mood: from Neuroscience to Intervention in the Aged

Major depression is a prevalent and debilitating condition affecting 1-3% of the elderly population, with clinically significant symptoms present in 8-16%. However, detection rates remain alarmingly low (<20%), and treatment effectiveness is moderate at best. Insomnia, a highly prevalent condition in older adults (up to 40%), is a significant risk factor for depression, increasing the risk by 13%. To address this critical issue, our proposal focuses on the development of a preventive intervention targeting insomnia in the elderly.

Our project aims to achieve three primary goals: early identification of at-risk individuals, quantification of underlying mechanisms, and enrollment in optimized intervention protocols. We will employ a multivariate trait analysis and brain imaging approach to identify insomnia subtypes and their corresponding mechanisms. Our interdisciplinary strategy will integrate expertise from neuroscience, psychology, and computer science to develop an internet-supported, home-applicable intervention format. The outcomes of this project will include subtype profiling, mechanism profiling, and intervention optimization, ultimately leading to sleep improvement and depression prevention in the elderly. By addressing the critical gap in insomnia detection and treatment, our project has the potential to significantly reduce the burden of depression in older adults, improving their quality of life and independence.
